content:
How to begin Introduction to Nutrition - Food for Health


We're excited to begin Introduction to Nutrition - Food for Health. There will be different reasons for you to take this course. In any way we would like to create awareness of the fundamentals of nutrition and how it can affect human health.
For us to offer the best learning experience possible, we'd like to ask you to answer a few questions about yourself. The more we know about you, the better we can serve all of the students in this course. As one of the first students in this new offering, your responses are particularly important to us. Please follow the link to the Pre-Survey.
Now you can start exploring Introduction to Nutrition - Food for Health by clicking on Courseware in the upper left (just below the edX logo). You can explore the first section:
Week 0: Introduction to the course
In Week 0 we'll let you know what to expect from the course, meet the course staff and read the instructions on how to work with the different learning activities and assignments.
You can visit the Discussion Forum. There is already a pinned thread where you can introduce yourselves. We'd really like to get to know our students!
If you haven’t done so already, we encourage you to check out edX101, a brief (10-30 minutes) walkthrough of an edX experience. It will help answer basic “how tos” on taking an edX course.
DECEMBER 16, 2014

Welcome!


Welcome to 'Introduction to Nutrition – Food for Health'. Together with 'Growing our Future Food: Crops', which starts on the 26th of January, this course is the first MOOC of Wageningen University.
Wageningen University is a life science university in the Netherlands which focusses specifically on the theme ‘health food and living environment’. Our mission is: “To explore the potential of nature to improve the quality of life.”
Follow us on Facebook and Twitter or visit our Website

Introduction to Nutrition - Food for Health


In the following weeks, you will learn the fundamentals of human nutrition and will go on a personal food quest
The course starts with two introductory modules. One to introduce the course, the teachers, and the participants, and the other to provide basic nutrition principles and facts necessary to continue with the rest of the course. Week 2 through 6 will focus on the three macronutrients carbohydrates, lipids, and proteins, and their influence on human health. Week 7 and 8 will zoom in on energy and weight management. In week 8 we will also wrap up the course.
The Courseware is where you will spend most of your time in the course. Every week one section will be released with video's, exercises, the Section Exam and Personal Food Quest.
You can see your Glossary in the Wiki page.
The course will remain open until March 15th. You have until that date to complete all the assignments marked as homework for the course (multiple choice quizzes, final exam peer review). At that point, if you have scored higher than 60% on the homework, you will receive a passing grade and be eligible to receive a certificate. This is a course for anyone who is interested in understanding human nutrition, how this influences health, and how to better weigh and interpret the information overload about nutrition and health.
Follow NUTR101x on Facebook and Twitter to stay up to date and meet your colleagues

Our lecturer


Dr. Kersten 
Dr. Sander Kersten is full professor of Molecular Nutrition in the Division of Human Nutrition at Wageningen University and holds an adjunct professorship in the Division of Nutritional Sciences at Cornell University. He received his MSc training in Human Nutrition at Wageningen University from 1989 to 1993. He subsequently moved to the USA and obtained his PhD in Nutritional Biochemistry from Cornell University in 1997. After a postdoctoral stint at the University of Lausanne, he moved back to Wageningen in 2000 to start his career as an independent scientist. Since that time he has been teaching introductory and advanced nutrition classes in the BSc and MSc program in Nutrition and Health at Wageningen University.
Course Calendar


The course will remain open until March 15th. You have until that date to complete all the assignments marked as homework for the course. However we advice you to finish the assignments by the end of the week as the adviced due dates suggests.
Week	What	Adviced due date
Week 0	Introduction to the Forum	19th of January
Week 1	Section Exam and Personal Food Quest	19th of January
Week 2	Section Exam and Personal Food Quest	26th of January
Week 3	Section Exam and Personal Food Quest	2nd of February
Week 4	Section Exam and Personal Food Quest	9th of February
Week 5	Section Exam and Personal Food Quest	16th of February
Week 6	Section Exam and Personal Food Quest	23rd of February
Week 7	Section Exam and Personal Food Quest	2nd of March
Week 8	Section Exam, Personal Food Quest and Final Exam	9th of March
Assessments and Grading


At the end of each week we will have an section exam, which is meant to test your comprehension of the course material for that week. There will also be a final exam, Final Peer review for grading, at the end of the course which tests on all the topics presented throughout the course. For those of you who are taking the course for a Honor code or Verified Certificate, you must meet a minimum grade of 60% in the course. The grading breakdown is such that section exams are together worth 80 % of your overall grade, and the final Peer review is worth 20 %.
Each assessment will be open at the time of the module's release. The deadline for all assessment and final peer review completion is one week after the end of the course (15th of March). In other words, you may choose to not to complete assessments of week 1 until the very end and it will still be open for you to do so. However, we recommend that you complete the assessments as you go.
Discussion forum and Google picture app guidelines


We hope that you find the discussion forums and the Google picture app to be a useful component of this online course. The discussion forums are meant to be an area where the students can interact with each other, ask questions, or talk to the course staff. We greatly encourage you to use these forums to their full extent.
To aid in this goal, we ask that you do not post comments which are derogatory, defamatory, or in any way attack other students. Be courteous and show the same respect you hope to receive. We will have discussion forum moderators who will delete posts that are rude, inappropriate, or off-topic. We also ask that you do not post answers to assessment questions on these forums. You may discuss how to approach a problem or help other students who may have questions, but please do not directly provide answers.
The Forum Guidelines will explain how to use the Discussion Forum . As also described below.
The Food for Health Photo app supports the Personal Food Quest you execute during the course. To keep the google picture app clean, we need your help. Place only relevant pictures on the Google map. Report non-relevant pictures by clicking on the abuse button wich is present in every uploaded picture. The forum moderators will receive a message. They check the picture and delete it if necessary.
Students who repeatedly abuse this public forum or the google picture app will be removed from the course.
Guidelines
Have faith that course participants are acting with best intentions. We’re all here to learn!
Posts should be written in your own words. If you include a quote or reference, when possible also provide a citation (book, URL, etc)
Participate! You will get out of the discussions what you put into them
Before posting, search the Discussion for similar questions or comments. You can always respond and/or click on the green plus button to upvote a post
If you disagree with a post, respond using evidence and reasoning instead of personal attacks
Before posting a comment, consider: would you say it to someone’s face? If no, we encourage that you revise it
Use correct grammar and spell-check your posts. Also, please do not use ALL CAPS
Avoid slang and abbreviations, as these vary across cultures.
Logistics
Please limit your posts/responses to 200 words or less (by request of EdX)
Use the search and engagement tools (upvote, follow for updates, flag for misuse) on the Discussion Home to find and contribute to the conversations
A blue star on a post means a member of the course staff has endorsed it
If you see an inappropriate post, flag it instead of adding your own commentary
Any technical questions or concerns should be posted in the Technical Questions Discussion
For more information on discussion forums, check out this blog post.
Getting Help


Finally if you have any questions, first check out the Frequently Asked Questions . If you cannot find your question there, feel free to ask questions in the Q&A section of the forum. The Forum Moderators will be hosting a few office hours throughout the course. If you need technical help using the edX platform, click on the “Help” tab, located on the top left corner of the browser screen.

Dear ENVSX Class Member,

Welcome! We’re so glad you’ve signed up for DartmouthX: Introduction to Environmental Science, which starts on February 3, 2015. There are more than 2000 students signed up from over 100 countries, so we are looking forward to an exciting exchange of ideas, information and experiences.

We will be contacting you again in December with updates on the following:
 - the ENVSX Community Page with links to our social media,
 - "Week 0” coming in January to allow us to get to know one another, and,
 - more information about the format and themes of the course. 

If you haven’t already seen it, check out the ENVSX trailer video here. 

Best wishes,

Andy Friedland, Professor of Environmental Science

On behalf of the entire ENVSX team.

Dear ENVX Class Member,

Hello again! Our course begins in under two months. We now have students enrolled from more than 150 countries and are excited about this diverse group. As promised, you can now find us on Facebook (fb.com/DARTX.ENVX) and Twitter (@DARTX_ENVX). 

The Dartmouth ENVX course is an abbreviated version of the introductory environmental science course offered at universities and colleges in the United States. As mentioned before, Week 0 will launch in January to introduce you to the course before it starts in February. We invite you to like the ENVX Facebook page and follow us on Twitter and are delighted to have you with us.

Best wishes,

Andy Friedland, Professor of Environmental Science
On behalf of the entire ENVX team.

P.S. If you haven’t already seen it, check out the ENVSX trailer video here.

Dear ENVX Class Member,

Hello again! Our course begins with Week 1 on February 3rd. Many of you have found us on Facebook and Twitter and some discussions have already started. 

Week 0 will be available on January 27th to introduce course objectives, schedule and logistics. In the meantime, if you are unfamiliar with the edX course system, we recommend taking the DemoX course before you begin ENVX.

Best wishes,

Andy Friedland, Professor of Environmental Science
Mike Goudzwaard, Instructional Designer
On behalf of the entire ENVX team

Dear ENVX Class Member,

“Pre-Course Introduction” (Week 0) is now live. Week 0 introduces course objectives, schedule and logistics prior to the official start date of the course. Click Courseware on the top menu from a web browser to access Week 0. 

ENVX begins with “Intro to Environmental Science” (Week 1) on February 3rd. 

Best wishes,

Andy Friedland, Professor of Environmental Science
Mike Goudzwaard, Instructional Designer
On behalf of the entire ENVX team

Dear ENVX Class Member,

We are delighted to let you know that “Intro to Environmental Science” (Week 1) is now available. This week, we will explore questions such as:

  • What is the difference between environmental science and environmental studies?
  • How does species diversity differ from ecosystem diversity?
  • Why is energy flow so important in environmental science? 
  • What is “Rock Snot”? 

We hope to hear from you in the discussion and question forums. If you have not had a chance to view Week 0, please start there or if you are ready, begin Week 1. 

To access the Courseware, click here.

Best wishes,

Andy Friedland, Professor of Environmental Science
Mike Goudzwaard, Instructional Designer
On behalf of the entire ENVX team

Dear ENVX Class Member,

“The Human Population” (Week 2) is now available. 

This week begins with a video recap of some of your discussion posts and highlights from Week 1 and then a transition to Week 2.
We explore questions such as:

  • How many people live on Earth right now?
  • What is the carrying capacity of Earth?
  • What is the relationship between the number of people, where they live, the resources they consume and their environmental impact? 

Finally we bring you a conversation with Phil Connors, an Australian Environmental Scientist, about human population and sustainability. 

Keep up the great work in the discussion forums, quizzes and helping each other out with questions.  To access Week 2, click here.

Best wishes,

Andy Friedland, Professor of Environmental Science
Mike Goudzwaard, Instructional Designer
On behalf of the entire ENVX team

Dear ENVX Class Member,

“Food and Soils” (Week 3) is now available. 

The week begins with a video recap of some of your discussion posts about human population and then transitions to our topic for this week. We explore questions such as:

  • What types of agriculture are used right now?
  • What is the difference between organic and conventional agriculture?
  • Why would you want to dig a soil pit?

We take you to visit an organic farm and we dig a soil pit in a forest. We have conversations with Danielle Allen, an organic farmer, and Justin Richardson, a soil scientist. 

Keep up the great work.  To access Week 3, click here.

Best wishes,

Andy Friedland, Professor of Environmental Science
Mike Goudzwaard, Instructional Designer
On behalf of the entire ENVX team

Dear ENVX Class Member,

“Non-Renewable Energy” (Week 4) is now available. The week begins with a video recap of some of the Your Favorite Meal discussion posts. This week, we explore:

  • How do we evaluate coal, oil and natural gas from an environmental science perspective?
  • What regulates energy conversions and losses in human-built systems? 
  • How much energy “flows through your fingertips?”

We take you on a tour of the Dartmouth Powerplant and have a conversation with Dartmouth Sustainability Director, Rosi Kerr. 

This week, we will offer an optional live office hour on Google Hangout. Please join us on Thursday, Feb 26 at noon (12:00pm EDT or 17:00 UTC). We will send an email tomorrow with details on how to join us. 

Keep up the great work.  To access Week 4, click here.

Best wishes,

Andy Friedland, Professor of Environmental Science 
Mike Goudzwaard, Instructional Designer 
On behalf of the entire ENVX team

On Thursday, Feb 26 we held an optional “office hour” on Google Hangout.

You can find the recording of this session in Google Hangout, watch on YouTube or watch in the window below.

____________

Please join us on Thursday, Feb 26 at noon, 12:00 pm EDT or 17:00 UTC, for an optional, live “office hour” which will run for approximately 30 minutes. 

Connect to Google Hangout on Air here or watch in YouTube here.

Post your questions in advance or during the Hangout. You can post questions in several ways: 

    • In the discussion forum here
    • In the Google Hangout during the event
    • On Twitter @DARTX_ENVX or on the ENVX Facebook Page

 Please join us tomorrow!

Dear ENVX Class Member,

“Renewable Energy” (Week 5) is now available. The week begins with highlights of some of your “energy that flows through your fingertips” discussion posts. They were great and some of the threads have 10-30 replies. This week, we explore:

  • What is renewable energy? 
  • How do we evaluate hydro, solar, wind and biomass from an environmental science perspective?
  • How can we increase efficiency and conservation?

We take a field trip to a PV tracker solar system, visit a straw bale house and have a conversation about waste vegetable oil as an energy source in India.  Keep up the great work.  

To access Week 5, click here.

Best wishes, Andy Friedland, Professor of Environmental Science 
Mike Goudzwaard, Instructional Designer 

On behalf of the entire ENVX team

Dear ENVX Class Member,

The final week of ENVX, “Global Change” (Week 6), is now available. We explore:

  • What is global change and how is it influenced by population numbers, and food and energy choices? 
  • What are some of the effects of global change on humans and natural ecosystems?
  • What are additional factors in evaluating personal environmental impact?

Some of you have been with us for the past five weeks and some of you are just starting the course now. Either way, you have until March 20th to finish all work. Certificates and Verified Certificates will be issued by March 31st.

If you enjoyed ENVX, please take a moment to write a brief review on Course Talk. We also have included an End of Course Survey for your feedback on ENVX. You will find this right after the Week 6 Quiz. 

To access Week 6, click here.

Best wishes, Andy Friedland, Professor of Environmental Science 
Mike Goudzwaard, Instructional Designer 

On behalf of the entire ENVX team

Dear ENVX Class Member,

The final week of ENVX is almost over. 

Because of time zone differences, we have added a small buffer: you now have until March 21, 2015 9:00 AM EST (13:00 UTC) to finish all work. Remember you need to achieve at least 60% to earn a certificate. Congratulations to the 1107 people have already passed the course! Some of you are really close so we encourage you to keep up the good work. Certificates and Verified Certificates will be issued by March 31st.

If you enjoyed ENVX, please take a moment to write a review on Course Talk. We also have included an End of Course Survey for your feedback on ENVX -- we value your thoughts. 

To access ENVX, click here.

Best wishes,

Andy Friedland, Professor of Environmental Science 
Mike Goudzwaard, Instructional Designer 

On behalf of the entire ENVX team

Dear ENVX Class Member,

ENVX ends on March 21, 2015 9:00 AM EST (13:00 UTC). Remember, you have until that time to complete any work. After that point you will be able to access the course archive on edX. 

Congratulation to the 1240 people who have already earned a Certificate!

We have really enjoyed interacting with so many of you over the last six weeks and are delighted to see all the positive comments. If you haven’t already, please take a moment to write a review on Course Talk and complete the End of Course Survey.

With all best wishes, 

Andy Friedland, Professor of Environmental Science 
Mike Goudzwaard, Instructional Designer 

On behalf of the entire ENVX team

Dear ENVX Class Member,

ENVX was offered from February 3rd to March 21, 2015 and is now archived. You can access all the videos, Check Your Understanding questions and weekly quizzes. The Discussion forums can be read, but are not open for new posts. 

Congratulations to the more than 1,370 people who earned a certificate. These will be issued on March 31, 2015 and we will provide and update on this page when certificates can be downloaded. 

If you enjoyed ENVX, please take a moment to write a review on Course Talk. We also have included an End of Course Survey for your feedback on ENVX -- we value your thoughts. 

If you are looking for another course to take, visit the DartmouthX page on edX to find other courses starting soon. 

With All Best wishes,

Andy Friedland, Professor of Environmental Science 
Mike Goudzwaard, Instructional Designer 

On behalf of the entire ENVX and DartmouthX team

Dear ENVX Class Member,

Thank you again for your work in ENVX. Although the course has concluded you can still access the archived course on edX. You can also access the videos on the ENVX YouTube channel.

Congratulation to the more than 1370 people who earned a certificate! For those who earned them, certificates are now available to download. The link to your certificate is on your student dashboard, the page you see when you first log into edX.

If you have any questions or difficulties, contact edX through the Help tab in the course. 

With all best wishes, 

Andy Friedland, Professor of Environmental Science
Mike Goudzwaard, Instructional Designer

On behalf of the entire ENVX team

Dear ENVX Class Member,

Welcome! We’re so glad you’ve signed up for DartmouthX: Introduction to Environmental Science (ENVX), which starts on June 15, 2015. This Dartmouth MOOC is an abbreviated version of the introductory environmental science course offered at universities and colleges in the United States.

We invite you to like the ENVX Facebook page and follow us on Twitter and are delighted to have you with us. ENVX was offered for the first time in February of this year and we were delighted to interact with so many engaged learners. There is already an active ENVX community on social media. Please join us there.

Best wishes,

Andy Friedland, Professor of Environmental Science 
Mike Goudzwaard, Instructional Designer 

On behalf of the entire ENVX team

Dear ENVX Class Member,

Hello again! Our course begins on June 15th, less than a week away. In the meantime, if you are unfamiliar with the edX platform, we recommend taking the DemoX course. We also wanted to provide an overview of the six major topics of the course. See the list below this message. 

A number of you have already found us on Facebook and Twitter. Please join us there.

Best wishes,

Andy Friedland, Professor of Environmental Science 
Mike Goudzwaard, Instructional Designer 

On behalf of the entire ENVX team

ENVX Topics:

Intro to Environmental Science: We will explore the field of environmental science and how to think like an environmental scientist. What is the difference between environmental science and environmental studies? How do both differ from environmentalism? Why is energy so important in environmental science? 

The Human Population: Understanding the human population and the ways in which changes in the population affect the environment is essential to environmental science. How many people are there living on Earth and where do they live? What is the carrying capacity of Earth?  

Food and Soils: Part of understanding human carrying capacity depends on knowledge of agriculture, soils and the environmental implications of eating different types of food. How does eating meat or vegetables, local or organic, sustainable or industrial foods affect the environment?

Non-Renewable Energy: Almost every aspect of our lives is dependent on energy. Non-renewable fossil fuels are an important source of energy in much of the world. What are the advantages and disadvantages to using coal, petroleum and natural gas? How does each contribute to greenhouse gas emissions? 

Renewable Energy: The use of renewable fuels such as wind and solar is growing rapidly around the world.  What are the benefits and consequences  of using each? Are “green” energy sources the answer to the world’s energy needs? 

Global Change: Human impact on biodiversity and global change are arguably the integrating units of environmental science. How are we affecting global change and biodiversity? How can we reconcile human population growth, resource demands and sustainability?

Dear ENVX Class Member,

The first three sections of ENVX are now available. In these first three sections we will explore the following questions:

“Intro to Environmental Science” (Week 1):

  • What is the difference between environmental science and environmental studies?
  • How does species diversity differ from ecosystem diversity?
  • Why is energy flow so important in environmental science? 
  • What is “Rock Snot”? 

“The Human Population” (Week 2):. 

  • How many people live on Earth right now?
  • What is the carrying capacity of Earth?
  • What is the relationship between the number of people, where they live, the resources they consume and their environmental impact? 

“Food and Soils” (Week 3): 

  • What types of agriculture are used right now?
  • What is the difference between organic and conventional agriculture?
  • Why would you want to dig a soil pit?

We hope to hear from you in the discussion forums. To begin the course, visit the Start Here section in Courseware.

Best wishes,

Andy Friedland, Professor of Environmental Science
Mike Goudzwaard, Instructional Designer
On behalf of the entire ENVX team

Dear ENVX Class Member,

Please join Prof. Andy Friedland and Mike Goudzwaard on Friday, June 19th at 11:00 - 11:30 am EDT or 15:00 - 15:30 UTC, for an optional, live “office hour."

You will be able to participate live on Google Hangouts on Air (sign up now) or on YouTube. There will also be a recording available here for viewing later. 

Post your questions in advance or during the Live Office Hour. You can post questions in several ways: 

• In the discussion forum

• In the Google Hangout during the event

• On Twitter @DARTX_ENVX or on the ENVX Facebook Page

Please join us on Friday!

Best wishes,

Andy Friedland, Professor of Environmental Science  
Mike Goudzwaard, Instructional Designer  

On behalf of the entire ENVX team

Dear ENVX Class Member,

Please join us TODAY (June 19th) at 11:00 - 11:30 am EDT or 15:00 - 15:30 UTC, for an optional, live “office hour."

You will be able to participate live on Google Hangouts on Air Post your questions in this discussion forum, on Google Hangouts, or on Twitter or Facebook.

It is the end of the first week of the course. We are delighted with the level of interaction and questions. Keep up the good work and remember that we will be launching the second half of the course on Monday, June 29th.

Best wishes,

Andy Friedland, Professor of Environmental Science  
Mike Goudzwaard, Instructional Designer  

On behalf of the entire ENVX team

Best wishes,

We take you on a tour of the Dartmouth Powerplant and have a conversation with Dartmouth Sustainability Director, Rosi Kerr. 

“Renewable Energy” (Week 5):

We take a field trip to a PV tracker solar system, visit a straw bale house and have a conversation about waste vegetable oil as an energy source in India.

“Global Change” (Week 6):

  • What are some of the effects of global change on humans and natural ecosystems?

Upcoming Events:

Please join us Wednesday, July 1st at 11:00 - 11:30 am EDT (15:00 - 15:30 UTC), for an optional, live "office hour." You will be able to participate live on Google Hangouts on Air or on YouTube. Post your questions in advance on this discussion forum.

Live Office Hour

10 July, 2:30 pm EDT (18:30 UTC)

Prof. Andy Friedland and Mike Goudzwaard hosted the third live “office hour." You can watch the recording on Google Hangouts on Air (sign up now) or on YouTube. 

Start watching at at 5:23.

Dear ENVX Class Member,

ENVX concludes this Friday, July 17th. Because of time zone differences, we have added a small buffer: you now have until July 18, 2015 9:00 AM EST (13:00 UTC) to finish all work. After that time, you will be able to access course materials, but not do additional work.

Remember you need to achieve 60% to earn a certificate. Congratulations to the 470 people who have already passed the course! Some of you are really close so we encourage you to keep up the good work to get to 60%! Certificates and Verified Certificates will be issued by July 30th.

Please take a moment to write a review on Course Talk. We also have included an End of Course Survey for your feedback on ENVX -- we value your thoughts. 

Best wishes,

Andy Friedland, Professor of Environmental Science 
Mike Goudzwaard, Instructional Designer 

On behalf of the entire ENVX team

PS If you are interested in signing up for a Verified Certificate, you have until tomorrow (July 15th).

We have also extended the deadline to sign up for a Verified Certificate to July 18, 2015 9:00 AM EST (13:00 UTC). 

Remember you need to achieve 60% to earn a certificate. Congratulations to the 570 people who have already passed the course! Some of you are really close so we encourage you to keep up the good work. Certificates and Verified Certificates will be issued by July 30th.

Best wishes,

Andy Friedland, Professor of Environmental Science

Dear ENVX Class Member,

If you enjoyed ENVX, please take a moment to write a review on Course Talk. We also have included an End of Course Survey for your feedback on ENVX -- we value your thoughts.

With All Best wishes,

Andy Friedland, Professor of Environmental Science 
Mike Goudzwaard, Instructional Designer 

On behalf of the entire ENVX and DartmouthX team
